title: Pacific Sunset From USS Manchester
Scopenote: This is a photograph of another unidentified United States Navy vessel with the setting sun in background, taken from the USS Manchester with her guns in the foreground. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: United States Navy Vessel Photographed From the USS Manchester
Scopenote: An unidentified United States Navy vessel is silhouetted against the horizon in a photograph taken from the USS Manchester with her guns in the foreground.

title: Pacific Sunset From USS Manchester
Scopenote: This is a photograph of an unidentified United States Navy vessel with the setting sun in background, taken from the USS Manchester with her guns and an unidentified corpsman in the foreground.

title: Curious Japanese On Lookers Gather Around USS Manchester Helicopter
Scopenote: Curious Japanese onlookers, mostly children, gather around the USS Manchester helicopter, nicknamed "Clementine". The helicopter was preparing to return to the USS Manchester after visiting Unzen, Japan.

title: USS Manchester Fires a Broadside Against Korean Installations
Scopenote: Muzzle flashes form a sheet of flame as the USS Manchester fires a broadside from its main and secondary batteries in the pre-dawn hours. The action took place near Kosang, Korea, as part of Task Force 95 bombardment of the Korean coast. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks. USS Manchester."

title: Dual Smoke Rings and Gun Flashes As USS Manchester Bombards Kosang, Korea
Scopenote: Gun flashes appear as the cruiser Manchester bombards the enemy coastline near Kosang, Korea. The Manchester fired 3446 rounds in three days of intensive shelling.

title: USS Manchester Fires Main and Secondary Batteries During Bombardment of Korean Coast
Scopenote: Muzzle flashes form a sheet of flame as the USS Manchester fires a broadside from its main and secondary batteries in the pre-dawn hours. The action took place near Kosang, Korea, as part of Task Force 95 bombardment of the Korean coast. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks. USS Manchester."

title: USS Manchester Fires Pre-Dawn Salvo Against Kosang, Korea
Scopenote: The forecastle of the USS Manchester is brilliantly lighted as the cruiser fires a pred-dawn salvo against Korean installations in Kosang, Korea area.  The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks After Hunting Trip
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks (left), of the USS Manchester, holds two birds he shot during a hunting trip during his rest and relaxation in Japan. He is standing next to an unknown Japanese hunting guide and dog.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks After Hunting Trip
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks (left) of the USS Manchester poses with two birds he shot during a hunting trip in Japan. Standing with Parks is an unknown Japanese hunting guide and dog.

title: United States Marines and Republic of Korea Marines
Scopenote: Two United States Marines and two Republic of Korea Marines sit in a wooden shelter during the capture of Sin Do Island, Wonsan Harbor Korea. All are unidentified.

title: Republic of Korea Marines on Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: Republic of Korea Marines gather around bonfires while on the snow covered beach of Sin Do Island, Korea in Wonsan Harbor.

title: Marines Capture Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: United States Marines walk along a snowy path in a heavily forested area of Sin Do Island located in Wonsan Harbor, Korea during assault and capture.

title: Marines Inspect Sin Do Island Fortifications Abandoned by Communist Forces
Scopenote: United States and Republic of Korea Marines inspect fortifications abandoned by Russian and Northern Korean forces on Sin Do Island in Wonsan Harbor, Korea.

title: Marines Gather at Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: United States Marines under Captain Hansen from the USS Manchester and Republic of Korea Marines gather on a snow covered beach of Sin Do Island in Wonsan Harbor, Korea.

title: Shelter on Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: Officers of a Soviet Combat Engineer regiment once billeted her according to the Russian inscription on the shelter on Sin Do Island, Korea.

title: Russian Writing on Shelter on Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: A shelter on Sin Do Island, Korea, has writing on it that indicates it was once occupied by a Soviet Combat Engineer Regiment. Original caption: Note the thickness of concrete and the Russian inscription on these fortifications in Wonsan Harbor.

title: United States Marines Walk Along Path on Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: United States Marines walk along a snow covered path in a forested area on Sin Do Island, Korea.

title: United States and Republic of Korea Marines Walk Down Hill
Scopenote: United States and Republic of Korea Marines walk down a snow covered hill on Sin Do Island, Wonsan Harbor, Korea. All are unidentified.

title: United States Marines at Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: United States Marines walk down a snow covered pathway in the forest of Sin Do Island, Korea in Wonsan Harbor during the assault and capture. All are unidentified.

title: South Korean Marines and United States Marines at Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: South Korean and United States Marines gather on a snow covered beach on Sin Do Island, Wonsan Harbor Korea. All are unidentified.

title: United States Marines in Wonsan Harbor, Korea
Scopenote: Marines from the USS Manchester under Captain Hansen and Republic of Korea Marines commence assault and capture of islands in Wonsan Harbor, Korea.

title: United States and Republic of Korea Marines on Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: Marines from the United States and Republic of Korea gather on beach on Sin Do Island, Wonsan Harbor, Korea. All are unidentified.

title: Sin Do Island, Wonsan Harbor, Korea
Scopenote: A makeshift shelter sits in a snowy, forested area of Sin Do Island, Wonsan Harbor, Korea, as United States and Republic of Korea Marines capture the island. All are unidentified.

title: United States Marines at Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: United States Marines capture Sin Do Island located in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. Small clusters of Marines can be seen near the coast on the snowy beach.

title: United States Marines and Republic of Korea Marines Land on Sin Do Island, Korea
Scopenote: United States Marines and Republic of Korea Marines gather on snow covered beach on Sin Do Island after it was captured.

title: USS Manchester Rearms in Wonsan Harbor, Korea
Scopenote: The USS Manchester rearms along side the ammunition ship USS Paricutin. The Manchester risked destruction in Wonsan Harbor for being in range of enemy forts during rearming.

title: USS Manchester Alongside USS Paricutin
Scopenote: The USS Manchester risks rearming in Wonsan Harbor, Korea within range of enemy forts. USS Paricutin, an ammunition ship, is alongside the Manchester to rearm.

title: USS Manchester
Scopenote: Photograph of the USS Manchester at sea.

title: Rear Admiral Lewis Parks Poses with Visitors Onboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Rear Admiral Lewis Parks (left) poses with two unidentified visitors to the USS Manchester.

title: USS Manchester
Scopenote: Photograph of the USS Manchester at sea.

title: Photograph of Rear Admiral Lewis Parks
Scopenote: An official photograph of Rear Admiral Lewis Parks.

title: Photograph of Rear Admiral Lewis Parks
Scopenote: Photograph of Rear Admiral Lewis Parks in his cold weather gear at work on the USS Manchester.

title: Injured are Transferred from USS Bass to USS Manchester
Scopenote: Crew members of the USS Bass help transfer injured crew members to the USS Manchester. The USS Bass was hit by enemy fire from Wonsan shore batteries in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. All are unidentified.

title: A Helicopter Lifts Off from the USS Manchester Deck
Scopenote: A helicopter can be seen in the far right of the picture as it lifts off from the deck of the USS Manchester on it way to assist a downed pilot. Air Force pilot Captain William R. Yoakley had crashed on the east coast of Korea and required rescue. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Captain Lewis Parks On the USS Manchester After Rescue of Air Force Pilot
Scopenote: Captain Lewis Parks (center) is on the bridge of the USS Manchester with two unidentified sailors. One of the men may be Captain R. Yoakley who was rescued after he parachuted from his damaged airplane just before it disintegrated. Captain Yoakley was rescued just as he hit the water and spent the next six days aboard the USS Manchester as it shelled Korean installations. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks. USS Manchester."

title: USS Manchester
Scopenote: Photograph of the USS Manchester at sea.

Scopenote: Photograph of Rear Admiral Lewis Parks in his cold weather gear at work on the USS Manchester.

Scopenote: Crew members of the USS Manchester help bring injured from the USS Bass aboard. The USS Bass was hit by enemy fire from Wonsan shore batteries in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. All are unidentified.

Scopenote: Photograph of the USS Manchester. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks.  USS Manchester."

Scopenote: Photograph of the USS Manchester at sea.

title: Photograph of Rear Admiral Lewis Parks
Scopenote: Photograph of Rear Admiral Lewis Parks.

title: USS Manchester Night Bombardment of Wonsan, Korea
Scopenote: The USS Manchester fires a six inch broadside salvo into Communist installations at Wonsan, Korea during naval bombardment by ships of Task Force 77.

title: Night Rocket Attack in Wonsan Harbor, Korea
Scopenote: Rockets from the USS Manchester fire upon a fort on the shore of Wonsan Harbor, Korea. Original caption: In a surprise night rocket attack with two LSMR's we attempt to destroy the enemy gun emplacements on the reverse slope of Kalma Gak - our most troublesome fort.

Scopenote: Photograph of the USS Manchester at sea.

Scopenote: Crew members of the USS Manchester help bring injured from the USS Bass aboard. The USS Bass was hit by enemy fire from Wonsan shore batteries in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. All are unidentified.

title: Truman Beach in Key West, Florida
Scopenote: View of Truman Beach in Key West, Florida, where President Harry S. Truman vacationed during his presidency.

title: USS Manchester Bombards Wonson, Korea
Scopenote: The blackened guns of the USS Manchester are in the foreground.  In the distance, a fuel dump that was hit by the Manchester's bombardment burns. In the center is a small island of Hwangt'o Do. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: President Harry S. Truman Arrives in Key West, Florida
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman's plane, the Independence, arrives in Key West, Florida. President Harry S. Truman greets Naval Officers after exiting the plane. At the foot of the stairs to the airplane is Admiral William Leahy (holding cane), General Harry Vaughan, and Admiral Robert Dennison. All others are unidentified.

title: President Harry S. Truman with Yeoman Emil Kesselman
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (right), seated at his desk at the Little White House in Key West, Florida, dictates a letter to Yeoman Second Class Emil Kesselman of the United States Navy Reserves. President Truman is in Key West for a vacation.

title: Front Lawn of Little White House, Key West, Florida
Scopenote: Members of President Harry S. Truman's vacation party are seated in the front lawn of the Little White House in Key West, Florida for a picnic lunch.

title: President Harry S. Truman Relaxing at the Beach in Key West, Florida
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman is relaxing on the beach in Key West, Florida, during his vacation trip. From left to right: General Harry Vaughan, General Wallace Graham, President Truman, Special Assistant to the President W. Averell Harriman, Administrative Assistant George Elsey, and Admiral Robert Dennison. The two men with their backs to the camera are unidentified.

title: Truman Beach, Key West Florida
Scopenote: Beach goers at Truman Beach in Key West, Florida. This photo was taken during one of President Harry S. Truman's vacations in Key West.

title: President Harry S. Truman at Fort Jefferson, Dry Tortugas
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman sits looking over the grounds at Fort Jefferson in Dry Tortugas, Florida. From left to right, Captain Cecil Adell, General Harry Vaughan, President Harry S. Truman, William Hassett, Joseph Short, and Admiral William Leahy. They are visiting Fort Jefferson during President Truman's vacation to Key West.

title: President Harry S. Truman's Aides En Route to Fort Jefferson
Scopenote: Members of President Harry S. Truman's vacation party are aboard the "Big Wheel," transferring from the USS Sarsfield to tour Fort Jefferson, FL. From left to right: Admiral William Leahy, General Wallace Graham, William Hassett, General Robert Landry, James Rowley, LCdr. Leo Roberts. President Truman is in the rear, in the white hat.

title: Members of President Harry S. Truman Vacation Party Fish
Scopenote: Members of President Harry S. Truman's vacation party pose for a photo with the fish they caught during their fishing trip off of Key West, Florida. From left to right: Colonel Francis Williams, Plane Commander of the Independence; Lieutenant Colonel Elmer Smith, First Pilot of the Independence; and William Hassett, Correspondence Secretary; unidentified man; and Horace D. Warden.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks Celebrates his Birthday
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks (right) cuts his birthday cake in the Wardroom of the USS Manchester. The other man is unidentified.

title: Arthur Prettyman Displays President Harry S. Truman's Key West Shirts
Scopenote: Arthur Prettyman, President Harry S. Truman's valet, displays President Truman's shirts that he wore in Key West, Florida during his vacation.

title: Men on the Beach at Key West, Florida
Scopenote: Members of President Harry S. Truman's vacation party relax on Truman Beach at Key West, Florida. Among those that can be identified are Eddie Jacobson (seated in shirt and slacks, left); John Steelman (standing, fourth from left, near post); Admiral Robert Dennison (standing, fifth from left, in dark sunglasses); Stanley Woodward (standing on opposite side of wall, in striped swim trunks); General Harry Vaughan (seated in from of Woodward, holding papers); and David Lloyd (seated, right). All others are unidentified.

title: Truman Vacation Party at the Beach at Key West, Florida
Scopenote: Members of President Harry S. Truman's vacation party relax on Truman Beach during a visit to Key West, Florida. Those that can be identified include Press Secretary Joseph Short (standing, third from left); John Steelman (seated, left); Stanley Woodward (sixth from left, standing behind wall); General Wallace Graham (seated, center, back to camera); and Admiral Robert Dennison (third from right, seated). All others are unidentified.

title: Press Secretary Joseph Short at Press Conference in Key West, Florida
Scopenote: Press Secretary Joseph Short (standing, second from left) holds a press conference in Key West, Florida. Mr. Short and members of the press are in Key West covering President Harry S. Truman's vacation to the area. Also present is Roger Tubby (standing, third from left, in dark-framed glasses). All others are unidentified.

title: President Harry S. Truman and His Party Arrive at Fort Jefferson
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman and his vacation party visit Fort Jefferson at Dry Tortugas, Florida. President Truman is leading the group (wearing white hat), all others are unidentified.

title: President Harry S. Truman attends Picnic at Fort Jefferson
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman attends a picnic at Fort Jefferson. He visited Fort Jefferson during his vacation trip to Key West, Florida. Far left: Press Secretary Joseph Short, unidentified (mostly obscured by tree), Administrative Assistant David Stowe, General Harry Vaughan, President Harry S. Truman, and Lieutenant Commander Leo Roberts. Others are unidentified.

title: Picnic at Fort Jefferson, Dry Tortugas, Florida
Scopenote: Members of President Harry S. Truman's vacation party at a picnic during a visit to Fort Jefferson, Dry Tortugas, Florida. Pictured from left: Admiral Robert Dennison, Matthew Connelly, Joseph Short, William Hassett, Admiral William Leahy, Lieutenant Commander Leo Roberts, and General Wallace Graham. All others are unidentified.

title: USS Manchester Docked at Yokosuka, Japan
Scopenote: The crew of the USS Manchester watches the welcoming festivities and anticipates permission to go ashore at Yokosuka, Japan. All are unidentified.

title: Various Ceremonies Take Place on the USS Manchester While Docked in Yokosuka, Japan
Scopenote: While a group of sailors are seated together in the background (rear of photograph), others enjoy the fun as a Japanese woman, a member of the welcoming committee, admires a sailor's ribbons on board the USS Manchester. The USS Manchester was docked at Yokosuka, Japan. All are unidentified. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Member of the Welcoming Committee Admires a Sailor's Ribbons
Scopenote: An unidentified Japanese woman, a member of the welcoming committee, admires to ribbons of a United States Navy corpsman while other bystanders take pictures and look on. These sailors are from the USS Manchester. All are unidentified.

title: USS Manchester Docks at Yokosuka, Japan
Scopenote: Corpsmen stand at ease awaiting permission to go ashore after the USS Manchester docked at Yokosuka, Japan.  The three Japanese women in traditional dress were the "welcoming committee." All are unidentified.

title: Margaret Truman in Sioux City, Iowa
Scopenote: Margaret Truman, right, stands with an unidentified man during a visit to Sioux City, Iowa.

title: Margaret Truman in Sioux City
Scopenote: Margaret Truman, right, stands with an unidentified young man, a member of the Future Farmers of America, in Sioux City, Iowa.

title: Margaret Truman Addresses Group in Sioux City
Scopenote: Margaret Truman (sole figure facing the camera) addresses a small group in Sioux city, Iowa.

title: Ivy W. Duggan and His Staff with the "Maid of Cotton," Jeannine Holland
Scopenote: Ivy W. Duggan, the Governor of the Farm Credit Administration, and his staff pose for a picture after a meeting. Standing in the front row, left to right: Carl R. Arnold; William T. McKeown; J. M. Selby; Thomas F. Murphy; Joseph D. Lawrence; Jeannine Holland, "Maid of Cotton"; Ivy W. Duggan; Henry P. Mousel; Cliff Woodward; and Edward F. Seiller. Second row, left to right (starting under the fan on the wall): Clay Mobley; Ernest Diebel; William Moore; Verne V. Hemstreet; Martin H. Uelsman; R. R. Clarke; Robert L. Farrington; Harold Hedges; Russell C. Engberg.

title: Senjin Lumber Camp On Fire After Bombardment by USS Manchester
Scopenote: The Senjin lumber camp is set afire by USS Manchester bombardment during siege of Wonsan, Korea. The photograph was taken from the Manchester's helicopter

title: Troop Billeting Area in Wonson, Korea Set Afire by USS Manchester Bombardment
Scopenote: Original caption: A Korean troop billeting area in Wonsan, Korea is set afire by the USS Manchester's main battery. The Manchester's big guns reached out as far as 13 miles to strike at enemy troop concentrations during the siege of the city of Wonsan. Troops are still visible in this photo taken from the Manchester helicopter.

title: Birthday Party for Captain Lewis S. Parks
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks celebrates his birthday with ward room officers while in Wonson Harbor, Korea. W. C. Hughes, Executive Officer stands next to Parks at the table where a cake has been placed. Others in the background are unidentified.

title: Injured British Pilot is Rescued by USS Manchester Crew
Scopenote: British fighter pilot Lieutenant Humphreys of Devon, England was shot down near the city of Hamhung, Korea was bought aboard the USS Manchester. He was rescued by the USS Manchester's helicopter piloted by Henry Cardoza, and Herbert Hicks. Lieutenant Humphreys was pinned in the wreckage and Hicks had to crawl inside the cockpit to release him. Humphreys suffered a broken leg, tipped fracture to the skull, deep laceration over his right eye and severe shock. He recovered in the USS Manchester sick bay.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks Cuts Birthday Cake
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks cuts into his birthday cake while standing next to W. C. Hughes, executive officer of the USS Manchester.

title: Commander F.D. Virgilie Inspects Wounded North Koreans
Scopenote: Commander F. D. Virgilie leans over a wounded North Korean while another unidentified officer watches. The damaged boat they are in has been brought along side the USS Manchester.  Others are unidentified. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Two North Korean Sampans Stored on the Fantail of the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Two North Korean sampans are stacked on the fantail of the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Dead North Koreans in a Damaged Sampan Alongside the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Naval corpsmen work to position a stretcher containing a dead North Korean in preparation from lifting the body aboard the USS Manchester.  The North Koreans are in a damaged sampan secured between the hull of the USS Manchester and a "whale boat." All are unidentified. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: A "Whale Boat" Helps Maneuver a Damaged North Korean Sampan Alongside the USS Manchester
Scopenote: A "Whale Boat" with sailors from the USS Manchester comes alongside a damaged North Korean small boat holdings three dead North Koreans. All are unidentified. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Dead North Koreans Are Brought Aboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Using a life line, the body of a dead North Korean is brought aboard the USS Manchester. All persons are unidentified. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: USS Manchester Crew Members Examine a North Korean Sampan
Scopenote: Unidentified members of the USS Manchester crew examine the damaged North Korean sampan brought aboard the USS Manchester and placed on the fantail.  The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Crewmen from USS Manchester Inspect the Damaged North Korean Sampan
Scopenote: Unidentified members of the USS Manchester crew inspect the damaged sampan stored on the fantail of the ship. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Crew of the USS Manchester Inspects the Damage Done to the North Korean Sampans
Scopenote: Unidentified members of the USS Manchester inspect the damage done to the North Korean sampans by the 5" battery. The sampans were brought aboard and placed on the fantail of the ship. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Harbor at Misaki , Japan
Scopenote: This is a photograph of the tuna boats in the harbor at Misaki, Japan. All are unidentified. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Pictures by R. Admiral Lewis Parks. USS Manchester."

title: North Korean Dead Are Brought Alongside the USS Manchester
Scopenote: A group of unidentified naval corpsmen maneuver a "whale boat" containing several dead North Koreans alongside the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks. USS Manchester."

title: North Korean Sampans on Fantail of the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Two captured North Korean sampans are secured on the fantail of the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: USS Manchester Corpsman Assists In Moving Body of North Korean to the Deck of the USS Manchester
Scopenote: An unidentified corpsman from the USS Manchester helps move the body of a North Korean from the "whale boat" to the deck of the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: United States Naval Corpsmen Prepare to Lift a Damaged North Korean Sampan Aboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: A group of unidentified naval corpsmen work in "the number #2 motor whale boat" to secure a damaged North Korean sampan in preparation for lifting it aboard the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks. USS Manchester."

title: Bringing a North Korean Sampan Aboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Unidentified United States naval corpsmen look on as a North Korean Sampan is brought aboard the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Close-up View of Captured North Korean Sampan
Scopenote: This is a close-up photograph of a captured North Korean sampan that is secured on the fantail of the USS Manchester.  An unidentified corpsman is seen in the background. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: United States Naval Corpsmen Carry Dead North Koreans Aboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Two unidentified corps men carry a stretcher with a dead North Korean aboard the USS Manchester. A group of unidentified naval corpsmen work in the "whale boat" where other dead North Koreans' bodies await transport. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks. USS Manchester."

title: Damaged Sampan Containing Dead North Koreans Is Secured Alongside the USS Manchester
Scopenote: An unidentified naval corps man works to secure a damaged sampan along side the USS Manchester. Three dead North Koreans can be seen in the sampan. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Confiscated North Korean Small Arms Displayed on the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Small arms confiscated from the North Koreans are displayed on the fantail of the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: North Korean Small Arms Taken at Wonson Harbor, Korea
Scopenote: Photograph of confiscated North Korean small arms taken at Wonson Harbor. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: North Korean Sampan Modified for Laying Mines
Scopenote: This is a captured North Korean sampan that has been modified to facilitate laying mines in Wonson Harbor. The sampan is sitting on the fantail of the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: North Korean Dead Being Brought Aboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: A group of unidentified American sailors work to bring the bodies of dead North Koreans aboard the USS Manchester.  The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: A Damaged North Korean Sampan is Hoisted Aboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Unidentified members of the USS Manchester crew assist as a North Korean sampan is hoisted aboard ship. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: North Korean Dead Are Loaded onto a Stretcher
Scopenote: A group of unidentified corpsmen work to load the bodies of dead North Koreans onto stretchers for lifting aboard the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: North Korean Dead Put On Stretchers in Preparation of Transporting Aboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: A group of unidentified United States sailors put the bodies of dead North Koreans onto stretchers in preparation for moving them aboard the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

Scopenote: United States naval team prepare to move the bodies of the dead North Koreans from the "whale boat" to the deck of the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Dead North Koreans in a "Whale Boat" Alongside the USS Manchester
Scopenote: A group of unidentified United States corpsmen maneuver a "whale boat" containing dead North Koreans alongside the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks. USS Manchester."

title: Personal Belongings of Dead North Koreans
Scopenote: Photograph of personal items found on the dead North Koreans brought aboard the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Harbor at Misaki, Japan
Scopenote: Men examine tuna in the fish market in the harbor at Misaki, Japan. All are unidentified. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Korean War 1950-1951."

title: Harbor at Misaki, Japan
Scopenote: Men unload tuna at the harbor at Misaki, Japan. All are unidentified. The photograph is part of an album entitled "Korean War 1950-1951."

title: Weapon Captured from North  Koreans
Scopenote: A "burp gun" and magazine captured from the North Koreans and taken aboard the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Partially Submerged North Korean Sampan is Brought Alongside the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Two unidentified naval corpsmen work to secure a partially submerged North Korean sampan alongside the USS Manchester.  North Korean dead can be seen in the water in the craft.  The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Close-up View of a Damaged North Korean Sampan
Scopenote: This is a close-up view of a damaged North Korean sampan. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Close-up View of a North Korean Sampan
Scopenote: This is a close-up view of a North Korean sampan secured on the fantail of the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: A United States Navy "Whale Boat" Secures a Damaged Sampan
Scopenote: A damaged North Korean sampan is secured to a naval "whale boat" and brought alongside the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: North Korean Sampan with Mine Laying Modifications
Scopenote: Three unidentified crew members from the USS Manchester examine the "4 X 4" that was added to the North Korean sampan to facilitate laying mines in Wonson Harbor. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Captain of the USS Manchester, Captain Lewis Parks, Examines Three Dead North Koreans Brought Aboard
Scopenote: Captain Lewis Parks, center facing camera, looks on while an unidentified corpsmen works with the bodies of the dead North Koreans that were brought aboard the USS Manchester.  The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Crew Member Fights Small Fire on USS Manchester
Scopenote: Original caption: Hot shell casings start a fire on their own as the USS Manchester big guns wage a duel with enemy shore batteries on the Kalma Gak peninsula in Korea. For almost an hour the Manchester kept up with a rapid continuous counter-battery fire as enemy shells exploded near the ship. As the hot shell casings piled up they ignited the cork used as spacers between the powder charge and projectile. They can be seen on the main deck. The fire was quickly brought under control by alert damage control personnel.

title: John D. Bryan is Carried Aboard USS Manchester
Scopenote: John D. Bryan, United States Navy, was carried aboard the USS Manchester after he was injured on the USS Bass in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. He later died from his injuries.

title: A USS Manchester Whale Boat Maneuvers a Damaged Boat
Scopenote: A damaged boat from the small boat flotilla that attempted to mine the USS Manchester, is maneuvered along side the Manchester by naval seamen in a United States "whale boat."  The sailors are unidentified. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Dead and Wounded North Koreans in Their Damaged Sampan
Scopenote: Taken from above, this photograph shows four North Koreans in their damaged sampan. Three of the North Koreans are dead but the one at the far left is alive but wounded. An unidentified corpsman stands in the far left of the photograph. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: United States Sailors Prepare to Move Bodies of North Koreans to the USS Manchester
Scopenote: A group of unidentified American sailors from the USS Manchester work to move the bodies of dead North Koreans from their damaged sampan onto stretchers. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Crew Members from USS Manchester Carry North Korean Dead
Scopenote: Two unidentified corpsmen carry the body of a dead North Korean on the port quarter deck of the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Captain Lewis Parks Views North Korean Dead
Scopenote: Captain of the USS Manchester, Lewis S. Parks, (center with hands on hips) view three dead North Koreans whose bodies had been brought aboard. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. All others are unidentified. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Confiscated North Korean Hand Grenades
Scopenote: Photograph of North Korean hand grenades brought aboard the USS Manchester. The North Koreans unsuccessfully attempted to mine the USS Manchester in Wonson Harbor off the coast of Korea. The photograph was in an album entitled "The story of the North Korean small boat flotilla who attempted to mine us in on [sic] a dark foggy night  R. Adm. Lewis S. Parks.  USS Manchester."

title: Rear Admiral Lewis Parks and Welcoming Committee at Yokosuka, Japan
Scopenote: Rear Admiral Lewis Parks poses with four Japanese women wearing kimonos who were part of the committee that welcomed the USS Manchester to Yokosuka, Japan. From left to right: Setsuko Kamagai, unidentified, Parks, Kimiko Ishimato, and Teruko Watanako.

title: Three Japanese Ladies Onboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: From left to right, Setsuko Kamagai, Teruko Watanako, and Kimiko Ishimato pose for a photograph in front of the guns of the USS Manchester while she is docked at Yokosuka Harbor.

title: Rear Admiral Lewis Parks with Yokosuka, Japan Welcoming Committee
Scopenote: Rear Admiral Lewis Parks (center) poses with Japanese women wearing kimonos who were part of the committee that welcomed the USS Manchester to Yokosuka, Japan. Left to right: unidentified, Setsuko Kamagai, Parks, Teruko Watanako, and Kimiko Ishimato.

title: Rear Admiral Lewis Parks with Yokosuka, Japan Welcoming Committee
Scopenote: Rear Admiral Lewis Parks (center) poses with Japanese women wearing kimonos who were part of the committee that welcomed the USS Manchester to Yokosuka, Japan. Left to right: unidentified, Setsuko Kamagai, Parks, Teruko Watanako, and Kimiko Ishimato.

title: Robert Farrington Takes Oath of Office
Scopenote: Robert Farrington (center) is being sworn in as Co-op Bank Commissioner by Arthur Thatcher (right), and Ivy W. Duggan (left).

title: President Harry S. Truman Attends the Armed Forces Day Parade
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman attends the Armed Forced Day Parade in Washington, D.C. From left: Secretary of Defense George Marshall, President Harry S. Truman, Major General Thomas W. Herren, General Harry Vaughan, Admiral Robert Dennison, and General Robert Landry. All others are unidentified.

title: Injured Transferred from USS Bass to USS Manchester
Scopenote: John D. Bryan of the United States Navy is bought aboard the USS Manchester after he was injured on the USS Bass in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. He later died from his injuries. All others are unidentified.

title: John D. Bryan is Brought Aboard the USS Manchester Injured
Scopenote: John D. Bryan of the United States Navy is carried aboard the USS Manchester after he was injured on the USS Bass in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. He later died from his injuries. Others are unidentified.

title: Sampan Inspected on USS Manchester's Deck
Scopenote: Crew members of the USS Manchester inspect a sampan that was loaded with explosives to serve as a mine in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. Two other sampan's are held over the deck by ropes.

title: Interior of Sampan Designed For Mines
Scopenote: Crew members of the USS Manchester inspect sampans brought on board the Manchester. Sampans were unsuccessfully used as floating mines in Wonsan Harbor, Korea. Original caption: Note installation of additional thwarts of new wood spaced for size of enemy in use plus securing lines for mines.

title: Two USS Manchester Crew Members Assess Mine-Laying Sampan
Scopenote: Communist forces planned to terminate the siege of Wonsan Harbor by using mine-laying sampans to destroy ships occupying the harbor. This sampan was discovered in an attempt to mine the ships.

title: Deceased North Koreans in Sampan Alongside USS Manchester
Scopenote: Communist forces loaded sampan boats with explosives to act as mines to end siege of Wonsan Harbor, Korea by United States and United Nations naval ships. The sampans were intercepted by radar and crew were killed. The sampans were brought the USS Manchester.

title: North Korean Guns, Rifles, and Grenades Found in Sampans
Scopenote: North Korean sampans were discovered in an attempt to mine ships in Wonsan Harbor. North Korean soldiers were killed and their boats were brought on board the USS Manchester for inspection. Rifles, tommy guns, and grenades were found in the boats.

title: Deceased North Koreans in Sampan Alongside USS Manchester
Scopenote: Communist forces loaded sampan boats with explosives to act as mines to end the siege of Wonsan Harbor, Korea by United States and United Nations naval ships. The sampans were intercepted by radar and crew were killed. The sampans were brought the USS Manchester. The man in the stern was unconscious but still alive and receiving help from crew members of the USS Manchester.

title: USS Manchester Hoists a North Korean Boat for Examination
Scopenote: The USS Manchester crew hoists a North Korean sampan aboard for further inspection while it is dark outside. North Korean troops planned to use sampans as mines to end the siege of Wonsan Harbor by destroying naval ships. All are unidentified.

title: Lewis Smith Parks Looks Over Deceased North Koreans
Scopenote: Captain Lewis Parks (center) looks over the deceased North Koreans killed in sampans loaded with explosives as they were brought on board the USS Manchester. All others are unidentified.

title: Deceased North Koreans Brought on Board USS Manchester
Scopenote: Crew members of the USS Manchester gather on the deck as three deceased North Koreans found in sampans are brought on board. Captain Lewis S. Parks looks over the dead. Others are unidentified. The North Koreans were killed as they tried to mine Wonsan Harbor and the USS Manchester.

title: Two Communist Mine-Laying Sampans
Scopenote: Two Communist mine-laying sampans are intercepted by USS Manchester crew members near Wonsan Harbor, Korea. Original caption: The Commies hatch a new plan to terminate the siege of Wonsan. At 0235 on 23 May 1951 a number of mine-laying sampans attempt to mine us in on a dark, foggy night. Our radar controlled guns disrupt the enemy plans.

title: President Harry S. Truman at the Dedication of Carter Barron Memorial Amphitheater
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (center) attends the dedication of the Carter Barron Memorial Amphitheater in Washington, D.C. Walking to the right of President Truman is General Harry Vaughan and General Robert Landry. All others are unidentified.

title: President Harry S. Truman Attends Dedication of Amphitheater
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman attends the dedication ceremony of the Carter Barron Memorial Amphitheater in Washington, D.C. From left, President Truman, General Harry Vaughan, and General Robert Landry. All others are unidentified.

title: Crew Members of USS Manchester Stand on Deck
Scopenote: The view from the USS Los Angeles as the USS Manchester passes. Manchester crew wrote messages to the Los Angeles in white paint on the ships side. Crew members from both ships were alongside their decks to greet each other. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief in Korea.

title: Messages Written on USS Manchester
Scopenote: Crew members of the USS Manchester stand along side the deck to greet USS Los Angeles crew. The Manchester crew wrote messages in white paint on the ship. The USS Los Angeles was to be the relief of the USS Manchester in Korea.

title: The USS Los Angeles Approaches the USS Manchester
Scopenote: View from the USS Los Angeles as the USS Manchester approaches. Crew members from both ships were alongside their decks to greet each other. The USS Manchester was traveling at full speed, as shown by the wake, as it was leaving Communist Korea after ten months at sea. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief.

title: Crew of the USS Manchester Greet the USS Los Angeles
Scopenote: The USS Manchester passes the USS Los Angeles, as seen from the Los Angeles. The USS Manchester crew wrote messages to the Los Angeles in white paint on the ships side. Crew members from both ships were alongside their decks to greet each other. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief in Korea.

title: USS Manchester Crew Greets USS Los Angeles
Scopenote: The view from the USS Los Angeles as the USS Manchester passes. Manchester crew wrote messages to the Los Angeles in white paint on the ship's side. Crew members from both ships were alongside their decks to greet each other. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief in Korea.

title: After Ten Months At Sea USS Manchester Prepares to Leave Korea
Scopenote: An unknown officer and sailor paint "Thank God our prayers have finally been..." on the side of the large guns aboard the USS Manchester as they wait for the arrival of the USS Los Angeles to relieve them from their ten month tour in Korea.

title: Message Written on USS Manchester for USS Los Angeles
Scopenote: The USS Manchester crew wrote messages to the crew of the USS Los Angeles in white paint on the ship's side. This was a reference to Rear Admiral Arleigh Burke aboard the USS Los Angeles. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief in Korea.

title: Crew Members of USS Manchester Greet the USS Los Angeles
Scopenote: The view from the USS Los Angeles as the USS Manchester passes. Manchester crew wrote messages to the Los Angeles in white paint on the ships side. Crew members from both ships were alongside their decks to greet each other. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief in Korea.

title: USS Manchester Passes the USS Los Angeles
Scopenote: View from the USS Los Angeles as the USS Manchester approaches. Crew members from both ships were alongside their decks to greet each other. The USS Manchester was traveling at full speed, as shown by the wake, as it was leaving Communist Korea after ten months at sea. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief.

title: Message Written on USS Manchester
Scopenote: Crew members of the USS Manchester wrote messages to USS Los Angeles on the metal exterior of the ship. Message reads "Choice Real Estate/ Kalma Gak/ Hodo Pando / 5 acres - 500 rds." Original caption: Two forts which frequently had us under fire - Kalma Gak and Hodo Pando.

title: USS Manchester Fires Guns in Front Line Troop Support
Scopenote: Original caption: At 18:31 the USS Manchester fires their last rounds in support of the front line troops on shore in Korea.

title: USS Manchester Passes the USS Los Angeles
Scopenote: The view from the USS Los Angeles as the USS Manchester passes. Manchester crew wrote messages to the Los Angeles in white paint on the ships side. Crew members from both ships were alongside their decks to greet each other. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief in Korea.

title: USS Manchester Fires Guns in Front Line Support
Scopenote: Original caption: At 18:31 the USS Manchester fires their last rounds in support of the front line troops on shore in Korea.

title: USS Manchester Crew Greets USS Los Angeles
Scopenote: The view from the USS Los Angeles as the USS Manchester passes. Manchester crew wrote messages to the Los Angeles in white paint on the ship's side. Crew members from both ships were alongside their decks to greet each other. The Los Angeles was the Manchester's relief in Korea.

title: Actress Monica Lewis and Captain Lewis S. Parks Aboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks, Commanding Officer of the USS Manchester, right, greets guests upon his return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. He presents Hollywood actress Monica Lewis with a custom life preserver from the USS Manchester. Others are unidentified.

title: Seaman Eugene Reddel and Monica Lewis
Scopenote: Seaman Eugen Reddel of Baytown, Texas, a member of the USS Manchester crew, poses for a photo with Monica Lewis, dubbed "Miss Manchester" by the Manchester crew during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California, after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Hollywood actresses Marilyn Monroe (seated, third from left), Carole Morton (seated fourth from left), and Dorothy Lamour (seated, right) are pictured in the background. All others are unidentified.

title: Actor Arthur Lake Aboard USS Manchester
Scopenote: Actors Arthur Lake stands at a microphones during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Various Hollywood actresses sit behind him, including Virginia Fields and Joyce McKenzie. All others are unidentified.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks, Zelda Parks, and Dorothy Lamour
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks, Commanding Officer of the USS Manchester, center, greets guests upon his return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Parks shakes hands with Hollywood actress Dorothy Lamour. Parks' wife, Zelda Parks stands to the right. Others in the background are unidentified.

title: Dorothy Lamour and Seaman Charles Ryan
Scopenote: Seaman Charles Ryan, a member of the USS Manchester crew, and Dorothy Lamour team up for a hula dance during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Others in the background are unidentified.

title: Seaman Eugene Reddel and Actress Monica Lewis
Scopenote: Seaman Eugen Reddel of Baytown, Texas, a member of the USS Manchester crew, blushes as Monica Lewis, dubbed "Miss Manchester" by the Manchester crew sings a lullaby during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Hollywood actress Joyce McKenzie is seated on the left. All others are unidentified.

title: USS Manchester Crew and Officers at USS Manchester Celebration
Scopenote: Part of the USS Manchester's officers, crew members, and their guests gather on the fantail of the ship to see the show put on by a Hollywood troupe, who met the Manchester on her return to her home port of Long Beach, California, after nearly a year of combat operation with United Nations Naval Forces in the Korean War. All are unidentified.

title: Dorothy Lamour at Microphone During USS Manchester Celebration
Scopenote: Dorothy Lamour stands on stage at a microphone during the USS Manchester's celebration upon arrival in Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Hollywood actresses are seated behind Lamour, including Joyce Mackenzie (left) and Monica Lewis (second from right). Standing in the background on the right is Captain Lewis Parks, commanding officer of the USS Manchester. Others are unidentified.

title: Seaman Eugene Reddel and Actress Monica Lewis
Scopenote: Seaman Eugene Reddel of Baytown, Texas, a member of the USS Manchester crew, poses for a photo with Monica Lewis, dubbed "Miss Manchester" by the Manchester crew during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Seated behind them are actresses Joyce Mackenzie (left) and Dorothy Lamour (second from right). Standing in the background is Captain Lewis Parks, commander of the USS Manchester. Others are unidentified.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks and Zelda Parks
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks gives his wife, Zelda Parks, a kiss upon his return to Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone aboard the USS Manchester.

title: Monica Lewis Gives Speech Aboard USS Manchester
Scopenote: Hollywood actress Monica Lewis gives a speech aboard USS Manchester during its arrival celebration in Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Captain Lewis Parks is in the background to the right. Also present in the front row are Virginia Field (left), Joyce Mackenzie (second from left), and Dorothy Lamour (second from right). All others are unidentified.

title: Seaman Eugene Reddel and Monica Lewis
Scopenote: Seaman Eugene Reddel of Baytown, Texas, a member of the USS Manchester crew, poses for a photo with Monica Lewis, dubbed "Miss Manchester" by the Manchester crew during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year.  Seated behind them are actresses Joyce Mackenzie (left) and Dorothy Lamour (second from right). Standing in the background is Captain Lewis Parks, commander of the USS Manchester. Others are unidentified.

title: Actress Monica Lewis Smiles for the Camera
Scopenote: Actress Monica Lewis stands at a microphone on stage during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. She is reaching for an autographed photo of herself. Hollywood actresses are seated her, including Carole Morton (second from left) and Dorothy Lamour (third from left, partly obscured). In the background, third from the right, is Captain Lewis S. Parks, Commanding Officer of the USS Manchester. All others are unidentified.

title: Seaman Charles Ryan and Dorothy Lamour
Scopenote: Seaman Charles Ryan, a member of the USS Manchester crew, and Dorothy Lamour dance the hula during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Hollywood actresses are seated behind them, including Monica Lewis, far right with Captain Lewis S. Parks, Commanding Officer of the USS Manchester behind her. Others are unidentified.

title: Unknown Man Stands at Microphone During USS Manchester Celebration
Scopenote: An unknown man stands at microphone during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Hollywood actresses are seated behind him, including Virginia Field and Joyce Mackenzie (left and second from left), Monica Lewis (second from right), and Dorothy Lamour (right). Standing in the background is Captain Lewis Parks, commanding officer of the USS Manchester. All others are unidentified.

title: Unknown Man Stands at Microphone During Manchester Celebration Show
Scopenote: An unknown man stands at the microphone as a part of a Hollywood troupe that performed aboard the USS Manchester during its return celebration to Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone. Seated behind him are actresses Virginia Field (left), Joyce Mackenzie (second from left), and Monica Lewis (second from right). All others are unidentified.

title: Arthur Lake and Charles Irwin Welcome the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Actors Arthur Lake (right) and Charles Irwin (left) stand at microphones during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Seated behind them is actress Joyce Mackenzie

title: Captain Lewis Parks and Zelda Parks
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks (back to camera) greets his wife, Zelda Parks, upon his return to Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone aboard the USS Manchester. Others are unidentified.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks Returns from Korea
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks, Commanding Officer of the USS Manchester, right, greets guests upon his return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. All others are unidentified.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks and Monica Lewis
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks gives actress Monica Lewis a kiss on the cheek during a party aboard the USS Manchester upon its return to Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Sailor in the background is unidentified.

title: Actress Monica Lewis and Seaman Eugene Reddel
Scopenote: Seaman Eugene Reddel of Baytown, Texas, a member of the USS Manchester crew, poses for a photo with Monica Lewis, dubbed "Miss Manchester" by the Manchester crew during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Captain Lewis Parks, is pictured in the background to the right. Seated on the left is actress Carole Morton. Others are unidentified.

title: Charles Irwin at USS Manchester Celebration
Scopenote: Actor Charles Irwin stands on stage during the celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Seated behind him are actresses Joyce Mackenzie (left) and Carole Morton (second from left). All others are unidentified.

title: USS Manchester Celebration Show
Scopenote: A troupe of Hollywood actors and actresses performed a show for crew members of the USS Manchester upon their arrival to Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Seated in the first row are Virginia Field (left), Joyce Mackenzie (second from left), Monica Lewis (third from right), and Dorothy Lamour (second from right). Standing in the background, second from right is Captain Lewis Parks, commander of the USS Manchester. Others are unidentified.

title: Actress Monica Lewis Aboard USS Manchester
Scopenote: Actress Monica Lewis (center) speaks with Captain Lewis S. Parks (back to camera) aboard the USS Manchester upon its return to Long Beach, California after being gone nearly a year in the Korean War Zone. All others are unidentified.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks with Monica Lewis and Jane Wyman
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks, fourth from left, poses with sailors and Hollywood actresses in front of a large cake shaped like the USS Manchester. The crew of the USS Manchester had just arrived to Long Beach, California after being in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Actress Monica Lewis, third from left, and singer Jane Wyman, far left. All others are unknown.

title: Seaman Charles Ryan and Dorothy Lamour Dance
Scopenote: Seaman Charles Ryan, a member of the USS Manchester crew, and Dorothy Lamour dance the hula during celebration of the USS Manchester's return to Long Beach, California after tour in the Korean War Zone for nearly a year. Hollywood actresses are seated behind them, including Monica Lewis, far right with Captain Lewis S. Parks, Commanding Officer of the USS Manchester behind her. Marilyn Monroe is standing next to Captain Parks. Virginia Field is seated on the left. All others are unidentified.

title: Hawaiian Welcome for USS Manchester at Pearl Harbor
Scopenote: Crew members of the cruiser USS Manchester received a typical Hawaiian "Aloha" on arrival at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Members of the hula troupe are Leilani Young, Gigg White, Mapela Dow, and Leimoni Hauenio. All others are unidentified.

title: Captain Lewis Parks and His Brother, John Parks Onboard the USS Manchester
Scopenote: Captain Lewis Parks (right) is pictured with his brother John Parks (left) on board the USS Manchester. The picture was taken upon the Manchester's return to Pearl Harbor after its tour in Korea.

title: Hawaiian Welcome for USS Manchester Crew
Scopenote: Crew members of the cruiser USS Manchester receive a typical Hawaiian "Aloha" on arrival at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii. Members of the hula troupe are Leilani Young, Gigg White, Mapela Dow, and Leimoni Hauenio.

title: USS Manchester in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii
Scopenote: The light cruiser USS Manchester, which had been operating in Korean war zone waters since September 13, 1950, with a carrier task force in the 7th fleet, arrives at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.

title: USS Manchester Docked at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii
Scopenote: Original caption: Arriving at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii is the light cruiser USS Manchester which had been operating in Korean war zone waters since September 13, 1950, with a carrier task force in the 7th fleet. Under the command of Captain Lewis S. Parks, the ship had relentlessly shelled the North Korean transportation facilities and provided close support for the United Nation Ground Forces. She would depart from Pearl Harbor from Long Beach, California.

title: Admiral Lewis Parks Poses for a Photograph
Scopenote: Admiral Lewis Parks poses for a photograph upon return to Pearl Harbor after his battleship, the USS Manchester, completed a tour in Korea.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks Addresses Sailors
Scopenote: With his back facing the camera, Captain Lewis S. Parks addresses sailors. All others are unidentified.

title: USS Manchester at Long Beach California Naval Station
Scopenote: The USS Manchester arrives at Long Beach, California naval station after a tour in the Korean War Zone since September 13, 1950.

title: Crew of USS Manchester Arrive in California
Scopenote: The crew of the USS Manchester arrives in Long Beach, California from the Korean War Zone. All are unidentified.

title: Hollywood Actors and Actresses Greet USS Manchester
Scopenote: The USS Manchester arrives in Long Beach, California after nearly a year on combat duty in the Korean War. Fourteen Hollywood actors and actresses were on hand to greet the returning officers and men. Actors and actresses that attended were Marjorie Reynolds, Margaret Sheridan (front row, third from left), Lisa Ferreday, Marion Marshall, John and Bobbie Sutton, Patricia and Arthur Lake, Charles Irwin, Alan Mowbray, Marion Davies, Dorothy Lamour (front row, fifth from right), Virginia Field (second row, behind Lamour, partly obscured), Marilyn Monroe (front row, fourth from right), Helena Carter (front row, third from right), Carole Morton (front row, second from right), and Joyce MacKenzie (front row, right). Others are unidentified.

title: Hollywood Actresses Greet the USS Manchester
Scopenote: On June 16, 1951, the USS Manchester arrives in Long Beach, California after nearly a year on combat duty in the Korean War. Fourteen Hollywood actors and actresses were on hand to greet the returning officers and men. Those shown, from left to right, Dorothy Lamour, Virginia Field, Marilyn Monroe, Helena Carter, Carole Morton, and Joyce Mackenzie.

title: General Robert Landry with Rear Admiral Marion Murphy at Guantanamo Bay
Scopenote: From left to right, Rear Admiral Marion Murphy, General Robert Landry, and Colonel Francis Williams at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. They are in Cuba during a stop of The Independence en route to Guayaquil, Ecuador, to pick up President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador.

title: General Robert Landry and Captain L.E. French at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba
Scopenote: General Robert Landry (left) and Captain L.E. French at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, during a layover of The Independence en route to Guayaquil, Ecuador, to pick up President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador.

title: President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador Boards The Independence
Scopenote: President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador boards the Independence for departure from Guayaquil, Ecuador for an official visit to the United States. All others are unidentified.

title: President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador Boards His Plane
Scopenote: President Galo Plaza Lasso (standing in door of airplane, waving) of Ecuador boards his plane at Quito, Ecuador for Guayaquil, Ecuador, to board the Independence for a visit to the United States. All others are unidentified.

title: President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador Arrives at Albrook Air Force Base, Panama
Scopenote: President Galo Plaza Lasso (left) of Ecuador arrives at Albrook Air Force Base in Panama en route to the United States for an official visit. Here is seen greeted by Brigadier General Emil Kiel, Commanding General of the Caribbean Air Command. Fifth from the left is General Robert Landry. All others in photograph are unidentified. In the background is President Harry S. Truman's airplane, the Independence.

title: President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador Leaves Albrook Air Force Base
Scopenote: President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador Leaves Albrook Air Force Base in Panama aboard Constellation 8608 headed towards the United States for his official visit. From left: Brigadier General Emil Kiel, Lieutenant General William Morris, President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador, U.S. Ambassador to Ecuador Paul Daniels, and Ecuadorian Ambassador to Panama Sixto E. Duran-Ballen.

title: General Robert Landry, Brigadier General Emil Kiel, and President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador
Scopenote: From left to right, General Robert Landry, Brigadier General Emil Kiel, Commanding General of the Caribbean Air Command, and President Galo Plaza Lasso of Ecuador at Albrook Air Force Base, Canal Zone for an unscheduled layover due to engine trouble of the Independence. Others in the background are unidentified.

title: President Galo Plaza Lasso with John F. Simmons and Captain Cecil Adell
Scopenote: President Galo Plaza Lasso (center) of Ecuador and his wife Rosario Pallares (third from left) chat with Chief of Protocol John F. Simmons (second from right) and Captain Cecil Adell (right) during a layover in Key West, Florida, en route to Washington, D.C. for the Ecuadorian President's official visit. All others in photograph are unidentified.

title: General Robert Landry in Tehran, Iran
Scopenote: General Robert Landry is standing beside an airplane at an airfield in Tehran, Iran. Other military officers are unidentified.

title: General Robert Landry and Lieutenant Colonel James Cole
Scopenote: General Robert Landry (left) and Lieutenant Colonel James Cole in Tehran, Iran.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks and Zelda Parks
Scopenote: Captain Lewis S. Parks and Zelda Parks are disembarking from a ship.

title: Ceremony for Changing of Commanding Officers
Scopenote: Captain Lewis Parks (standing at microphone) is speaking during the ceremony turning over command of the USS Manchester to Captain Laurence Frost (seated, left). All others are unidentified.

title: Captain Lewis Parks and Captain Lawrence Frost
Scopenote: Sailors are inspected during a ceremony for changing of commanding officers aboard the USS Manchester. Captain Lewis Parks (center, right) hands over duty to Captain Laurence Frost (center foreground, left). All others are unidentified.

title: Ceremony for Changing of Commanding Officers
Scopenote: Sailors are standing during a ceremony for the changing of commanding officers aboard the USS Manchester. Captain Lewis Parks hands over duty to Captain Laurence Frost. All are unidentified.

title: Captain Laurence Frost and Captain Lewis S. Parks
Scopenote: Captain Laurence Frost (left) stands at the microphone during the change of commanding officer's ceremony next to Captain Lewis S. Parks (right) aboard the USS Manchester. All others are unidentified.

title: Captain Laurence Frost and Captain Lewis S. Parks
Scopenote: Captain Laurence Frost (second from left) takes over command of the USS Manchester from Captain Lewis S. Parks (third from left) in Long Beach, California. They are inspecting a group of Marines. All others are unidentified.

title: Captain Lewis S. Parks and Captain Lawrence Frost
Scopenote: Captain Lewis Parks (right) shakes hands with Captain Laurence Frost (left) during a ceremony in which Captain Parks hands over the command of the USS Manchester to Captain Frost. All others are unidentified.

title: Captain Laurence Frost Takes Command of USS Manchester
Scopenote: Captain Laurence Frost (foreground, center) takes command of the USS Manchester during a ceremony aboard the ship. He is reviewing sailors standing at attention. Behind him is Captain Lewis Parks (center, third from the front). All others are unidentified.

title: Turning Over Command of USS Manchester
Scopenote: Sailors are seated during a ceremony to turn over command of the USS Manchester from Captain Lewis S. Parks to Captain Laurence Frost. The ceremony was held aboard ship with officers and crew members. All are unidentified.

title: Changing of Commanding Officers Aboard USS Manchester
Scopenote: Marines are undergoing inspection during a ceremony for changing of commanding officers aboard the USS Manchester. Captain Lewis Parks (middle row, third from left) hands over duty to Captain Laurence Frost (middle row, second from left). All others are unidentified.

title: President Harry S. Truman Meets With  Agriculture Associates
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman is shown conversing with agriculture figures in the oval office. From left to right stands John W. Snyder the Secretary of the Treasury, President Harry S. Truman, Charles F. Brannan the Secretary of Agriculture, and Ivy W. Duggan the Governor of the Farm Credit Administration.

title: President Harry S. Truman Attends Formal Presentation of Statues at Memorial Bridge
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman attends a formal presentation of equestrian statues, "The Art of War" and "The Art of Peace," by Italian Prime Minister Alcide de Gasperi to the Government of the United States at Memorial Bridge in Washington, D.C. At podium is Prime Minister de Gasperi, behind is President Harry S. Truman. Left of podium is Secretary of State Dean Acheson. All others are unidentified.

title: Lieutenant Charles G. Jones
Scopenote: This is a portrait of Lieutenant Charles Jones, the captain of the USS Manchester's helicopter, "Clementine". The photograph was taken just prior to the donning flight for the trip that was to be Clementine's last. The helicopter was shot down during a rescue mission for a Navy pilot in Korea. Jones survived the crash.

title: Colonel David Schilling Receives the Harmon International Trophy
Scopenote: Colonel David Schilling, fourth from the left, receives the Harmon International Trophy in the Rose Garden at the White House. Schilling had been selected as the outstanding aviator for 1950. On September 22, 1950, Colonel Schilling successfully flew a Republic F-84E Thunderjet from Manston, England, to Limestone Air Force Base in Maine, accomplishing by means of in-flight refueling the first nonstop transatlantic jet aircraft flight. All others are unidentified.

title: President Harry S. Truman Presents Trophy to Colonel David Schilling
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (left) presents the Harmon International Trophy to Colonel David Schilling (second from left), United States Air Force, who had been selected as the outstanding aviator for 1950. Others in the photo are unidentified.

title: Colonel David Schilling at Reception for Receiving Harmon International Trophy
Scopenote: Colonel David Schilling (left) is with two other unidentified men during reception after receiving the Harmon International Trophy presented to him by President Harry S. Truman.

title: President Harry S. Truman Presents Trophy to Colonel David Schilling
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (left) presents the Harmon International Trophy to Colonel David Schilling, United States Air Force (right), who had been selected as the outstanding aviator for 1950. Standing in the background from left to right is Secretary of the Air Force Thomas Finletter, Secretary of Defense Robert Lovett, Secretary of the Army Frank Pace, and two unidentified men. All others are unidentified.

title: Harmon Trophy Presentation Luncheon
Scopenote: Men are seated at a table at the Harmon Trophy Presentation Luncheon. General Robert Landry is at the far right. All others are unidentified.

title: Harmon Trophy Presentation and Luncheon
Scopenote: An unidentified military officer stands at a table surrounded by people seated at the Harmon Trophy Presentation and Luncheon. General Robert Landry is pictured second from right. All others are unidentified.

title: Harmon Trophy Presentation and Luncheon
Scopenote: Men and military officers are seated at a table during the Harmon Trophy Presentation and Luncheon. All are unidentified.

title: President Harry S. Truman Presents Trophy to Colonel David Schilling and Associates
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman (left) presents the Harmon International Trophy to Colonel David Schilling, United States Air Force (right), who was selected as the outstanding aviator for 1950. Standing in the background, are, from left to right, Secretary of the Air Force Thomas Finletter, Secretary of Defense Robert Lovett, Secretary of the Army Frank Pace, and two other unidentified men. Other associates in photo are unknown.

title: Harmon International Trophy Presentation to Colonel David Schilling
Scopenote: Colonel David Schilling (right) holds the Harmon International Trophy as he talks with an unidentified armed forces officer.

title: Seated Guests at Harmon Trophy Presentation and Luncheon
Scopenote: Guests are seated at their tables at the Harmon Trophy Presentation and Luncheon. All are unidentified.

title: Harmon Trophy Presentation and Luncheon
Scopenote: Unknown military officers pose for a photo at the Harmon Trophy Presentation and Luncheon.

title: General Robert Landry Greets Mrs. Vandenberg
Scopenote: General Robert Landry at the annual reception given by the Director of Intelligence for the Air Attache Corps at the Officers Club at Bolling Air Force Base, Washington D.C. From left: Mrs. Lehman, General Robert Landry, Mrs. Cabell, and Mrs. Vandenberg

title: Princess Elizabeth Arrives in Washington D.C
Scopenote: Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip of Great Britain arrive in Washington D.C. and are greeted by President Harry S. Truman. In front are (from left to right): Prince Philip, Princess Elizabeth, and President Harry S. Truman. In the row directly behind President Truman is (from left to right) General Harry Vaughan, Admiral Robert Dennison, and General Robert Landry.
